thread.title: Pune Test: Bizarre scenes as Matt Renshaw leaves batting crease with upset stomach : Cricket, News - India Today
thread.title_full: Pune Test: Bizarre scenes as Matt Renshaw leaves batting crease with upset stomach : Cricket, News - India Today

title: Pune Test: Bizarre scenes as Matt Renshaw leaves batting crease with upset stomach : Cricket, News - India Today
text:
Renshaw retired ill after scoring 36 off 89 balls 2 Marsh walked in to replace him at the middle 3 Renshaw didn't come out after the fall of Marsh's wicket as well 
There were some bizarre scenes on the first morning of the opening Test between India and Australia in Pune . 
It all began nicely enough for Australia, who batted after winning the toss. Openers David Warner and Matt Renshaw battled hard against India's spinners. Warner even survived a dismissal off a no-ball from Jayant Yadav and then had a close shave against R Ashwin. 
But then, just when the dangerous southpaw was settled, he was bowled by Umesh Yadav in his first over of the match. And then, as Steve Smith walked out to the middle, Renshaw jogged past him clutching his stomach. ( Also read: Five reasons why Australia should be wary of Virat Kohli's Invincibles ) 
The Australian captain was bemused and lost. What was happening out there? Renshaw had batted brilliantly up until that point, using his feet smartly against the spin of Ashwin, Jayant and Ravindra Jadeja . ( Also read: Australia will come hard at Virat Kohli in first Test: Sourav Ganguly to India Today ) 
The 20-year-old had impressed in four Tests in the Australian summer and was playing his first Test outside his country. Renshaw had moved to 36 off 89 balls which included a six off Jadeja and it looked like he could offer some resistance to India's hostile spin attack but it came to an end in a rather comical fashion. ( Also read: India vs Australia: Steve Smith brushes aside Harbhajan Singh's 4-0 forecast ) 
The young batsman must have had some embarrassing moments on the field - he had reached the boundary line before the umpires called him back to the field to ask what was going on. He was then asked to leave after being told that he could come in to bat only at the fall of the next wicket. That left Shaun Marsh little time to rush out to the crease. Reuters Photo 
After a brief partnership promised to offer some solace to Australia, Marsh perished to Jayant. However, there was still no sign of Renshaw as Peter Handscomb joined Smith in the middle. 
Former Australian captain Michael Clarke, who was on air for Star Sports commentary duties, was left stunned with the development minutes before lunch. 
"What is going on here? He's retiring ill," former Test skipper Michael Clarke said on Star Sports commentary after watching the unusual situation unfold. "There's only 15 minutes to lunch. I can't believe Renshaw's retiring. He must be extremely sick with a stomach bug and has to go to the bathroom. 
"This is unbelievable for Australia. "Steve Smith didn't know what was going on. He walked onto the field after the dismissal of David Warner and his partner walked straight past him." 
Another former Australian captain, Allan Border, was not happy with Renshaw's decision to go off the field with 15 minutes left for lunch. He expressed his displeasure on Fox Sports. "It's such a shame, we saw him having to go off 15 minutes before lunch. I hope he is lying on the table there half dead otherwise as a captain I would not be happy." 
However, Renshaw redeemed himself when he resumed his innings at the fall of Peter Handscomb's wicket and struck his second half-century. He remained firm at one end while Australia kept losing wickets at the other.
